column9: C1. Public funds should pay for biobanks, instead of private companies.
column10: C2. The community that donates samples for research should receive improved medical services.
column11: C3. All participants should be paid for donating their samples to a biobank.
column12: C4. Genetic information is different from health information.
column13: C5. The confidentiality of personal medical information is critical in any circumstance where research is being conducted.
column14: C6. High-priced genetic research is diverting funds that could be used to promote public health.
column15: C7. Race is a useful topic for genetic studies.
column16: C8. Sampling some people in an ethnocultural community is acceptable only if the whole ethnocultural community has agreed to participate.
column17: C9. To me, religious communities need to be consulted about genetic and biobank research.
column18: C10. Genetic studies of disability will lead to the discrimination of people living with the same conditions.
column19: C11. Genetic studies of race on enthocultural communities will lead to the discrimination of those same enthocultural communities.
column20: C12. The priority for healthcare should be to reduce inequalities and the burden of disease.
column21: C13. Biobanks are useful even if they only produce more scientific knowledge and not medical advancements.
column22: C14. It is always permissible to do research on my personally identifiable sample without my prior permission.
column23: C15. There is no point in consulting the public about ethical issues in science and technology.
column24: C16. Genetic research will improve our lives.
column25: C17. Deciding how to regulate biobanks should be left to the government.
column26: C18. There is no risk to the participants who donate to biobanks.
column27: C19. Policy makers should consider the possibility that Canada should not pursue biobanking.
column28: C20. My personal sample should never be anonymized since I should be informed of important research results.
column29: C21. Researchers should be allowed to use samples for research but they should not own them.
column30: C22. Participants should be contacted every time researchers want to use their samples for research.
column31: C23. Aboriginal communities require special consideration concerning healthcare and research.
column32: C24. Educating people about health issues (e.g. diet and lifestyle changes) promises greater health effects than investing in biobanks.
column33: C25. If someone is a carrier of a genetic disease, they have a responsibility to participate in genetic research.
column34: C26. Participants should always be able to withdraw their sample from research at anytime.
column35: C27. I should have property rights to my tissues before or after they leave my body.
column36: C28. Participants who donate their samples for research should be given special access to the treatments and therapies that result from that research.
column37: C29. Permission from the indigenous community must be sought if samples are collected from indigenous peoples.
column38: C30. Participants should be active in the set up and oversight of  biobanks.
column39: C31. Biobanks will only lead to expensive treatments and high profits.
column40: C32. Scientists should have access to all unidentified, personal samples for research.
column41: C33. Biobanks need independent review boards to determine who should have access to samples.
column42: C34. I trust researchers to control access to my personal samples.
column43: C35. Everyone should donate samples to a biobank for the benefit of everyone.
column44: C36. I do not care if my donated sample is connected to my name and medical information.
column45: C37. The fact that we cannot predict what biobanks will be used for bothers me.
column46: C38. Profits from biobanking should be returned to the donating community.
